The instrumental record may provide data that allow us to outline the limits of where humans have grown crops in the present day. However, not all areas of the world have high-resolution spatial data on where crops are grown, nor do these records often distinguish between the type of crop grown. One such useful dataset exists for the People’s Republic of China—the China Vegetation Atlas, a 1:1,000,000 scale vegetation distribution map of China of data collected between the 1950s and 1980s (
57 ). Niche probability data were generated for the 1960–1990 calibration period using the same data for traditional cultivars we used in the rest of our analysis ( Figs. 5 and 6). Because of the difficulty of accessing the China Vegetation Atlas in the United States, we have archived it in the Digital Archaeological Record (ID: 442484) at https://doi.org/10.6067/XCV85B05BG.
